newsitem.title: UNITED NATIONS: U.N. says Afghan meeting sent "resounding message".
newsitem.headline: U.N. says Afghan meeting sent "resounding message".

text.p: Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali believed a meeting on Afghanistan at U.N. headquarters on Monday sent a "resounding message to the Afghan factions" that there was no military solution to the conflict, U.N. spokesman Sylvana Foa said on Tuesday.
The meeting was attended by participants from 19 countries and the Organisation of the Islamic Conference, which all have influence on one or more of the factions.

"The secretary-general feels the meeting sent a resounding message to the Afghan factions," Foa said. All participants "expressed their conviction that there is no military solution to the conflict there."

"They want an immediate ceasefire, which in the view of almost all of them should include the demilitarization of Kabul. They want the Afghan parties to join in a genuine effort to find a political settlement to their conflict. They all expressed their readiness to join in coordinated international efforts to help the Afghans achieve this."

All the delegations said the "present situation cannot be allowed to continue," Foa said. It was "intolerable in terms of the suffering it imposes on the Afghan people...in terms of the threats it presents to the region and the world -- the threats of regional destabilisation, of drugs, of illegal arms flows, of terrorism."
The delegations also showed a keen interest in collective action to curb or halt the flow of arms and ammunition into Afghanistan.
Afghanistan's radical Taleban movement, which captured Kabul, the capital, in late September, on Tuesday dismissed the U.N. meeting as contrary to the wishes of the Afghan people.

"Any conference, meeting...regarding Afghanistan without Afghanistan's representatives is a useless action," said a commentary by the official Bakhtar news agency broadcast by the Taleban-controlled Kabul Radio.

The head of the U.N. special mission in Afghanistan, German diplomat Norbert Holl, who attended Tuesday's meeting, told a news conference he would attend an "Afghan forum" originally scheduled for Dec. 2-3 in Peshawar, across the border in Pakistan, but now likely to be held elswhere due to "political problems."
Another U.N. source said the gathering, mainly to discuss humanitarian activities in Afghanistan, might now take place in Geneva on Dec. 3-4.
